elements.content: The reaction of uranyl nitrate with terephthalic acid (H 2 TP) under hydrothermal conditions in the presence of an organic base, 1,3-(4,4′-bispyridyl)­propane (BPP) or 4,4′-bipyridine (BPY), provided four uranyl terephthalate compounds with different entangled structures by a pH-tuning method. [UO2(TP)1.5]­(H2 BPP)0.5·2H2O (1) obtained in a relatively acidic solution (final aqueous pH, 4.28) crystallizes in the form of a noninterpenetrated honeycomb-like two-dimensional network structure. An elevation of the solution pH (final pH, 5.21) promotes the formation of a dimeric uranyl-mediated polycatenated framework, [(UO2)2(μ-OH)2(TP)2]2(H2 BPP)2·4.5H2O (2). Another new polycatenated framework with a monomeric uranyl unit, [(UO2)2(TP)3]­(H2 BPP) (3), begins to emerge as a minor accompanying product of 2 when the pH is increased up to 6.61, and turns out to be a significant product at pH 7.00. When more rigid but small-size BPY molecules replace BPP molecules, [UO2(TP)1.5]­(H2 BPP)0.5 (4) with a polycatenated framework similar to 3 was obtained in a relatively acidic solution (final pH, 4.81). The successful preparation of 2–4 represents the first report of uranyl–organic polycatenated frameworks derived from a simple H 2 TP linker. A direct comparison between these polycatenated frameworks and previously reported uranyl terephthalate compounds suggests that the template and cavity-filling effects of organic bases (such as BPP or BPY), in combination with specific hydrothermal conditions, promote the formation of uranyl terephthalate polycatenated frameworks.

elements.content: A series of novel uranyl terephthalate polycatenated frameworks have been synthesized from uranyl nitrate and terephthalic acid through a templated-synthesis method using organic bases, 1,3-(4,4′-bispyridyl)­propane (BPP) or 4,4′-bipyridine (BPY), for the first time. The vital role of organic base as the template agent has been demonstrated by a direct comparison between these polycatenated frameworks and previously reported uranyl terephthalate compounds, as well as by density functional theory calculations.
elements.clean_text: A series of novel uranyl terephthalate polycatenated frameworks have been synthesized from uranyl nitrate and terephthalic acid through a templated-synthesis method using organic bases, 1,3-(4,4'-bispyridyl)propane (BPP) or 4,4'-bipyridine (BPY), for the first time. The vital role of organic base as the template agent has been demonstrated by a direct comparison between these polycatenated frameworks and previously reported uranyl terephthalate compounds, as well as by density functional theory calculations.

elements.content: Actinide-bearing hybrid materials, especially actinide coordination compounds, have drawn much attention from chemists and material scientists, and considerable research efforts have been devoted to this field because of its relevance to nuclear waste management, as well as the intriguing 5f bonding features of actinide elements. As one of the most extensively studied actinides, uranium is incorporated in numerous actinide–organic coordination polymers in two oxidation states, U­(VI) and U­(IV). Compared to oxygen-sensitive U­(IV), U­(VI), which occurs primarily as the linear uranyl cation ([UO2]2+), is stable under an ambient atmosphere and has accordingly been studied more extensively. The inactive terminal oxo groups of uranyl often prevent axial bonding interactions, resulting in any further coordination occurring in the equatorial plane. As a result, uranyl–organic coordination polymers usually prefer to form one-dimensional (1D) chains or two-dimensional (2D) sheets rather than three-dimensional (3D) frameworks that require structural connectivity in the third dimension.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Actinide-bearing hybrid materials, especially actinide coordination compounds, have drawn much attention from chemists and material scientists, and considerable research efforts have been devoted to this field because of its relevance to nuclear waste management, as well as the intriguing 5f bonding features of actinide elements. As one of the most extensively studied actinides, uranium is incorporated in numerous actinide-organic coordination polymers in two oxidation states, U(VI) and U(IV). Compared to oxygen-sensitive U(IV), U(VI), which occurs primarily as the linear uranyl cation ([UO2]2+), is stable under an ambient atmosphere and has accordingly been studied more extensively. The inactive terminal oxo groups of uranyl often prevent axial bonding interactions, resulting in any further coordination occurring in the equatorial plane. As a result, uranyl-organic coordination polymers usually prefer to form one-dimensional (1D) chains or two-dimensional (2D) sheets rather than three-dimensional (3D) frameworks that require structural connectivity in the third dimension.

elements.content: 2D networks or 3D frameworks with large cavities or pores can readily achieve a high degree of self-assembly by an entangled mode in the solid state and thus afford a variety of intriguing topological structures as well as fascinating properties. Generally, the different types of entangled systems that have been reported can be classified as interpenetrated, polycatenated (parallel or inclined), or Borromean-linked arrays depending on the assembly patterns. Polycatenation essentially always promotes an increase in the dimensionality of the final assemblies in comparison with the dimensionality of the basic building motifs, whereas there is generally no change in the dimensionality for the interpenetration or Borromean-type assembly modes. This is also the case for uranyl–organic compounds, especially those in 2D networks, which can assemble in similar entangled patterns. For example, several uranyl-based cases, including parallel 2D + 2D → 2D interpenetration, have been reported. In comparison to a relatively large number of uranyl–organic compounds exhibiting parallel interpenetration, polycatenatenation remains rare for uranyl–organic compounds. The first case of a polycatenatenated uranyl–organic compound, reported by Cahill in 2006, was assembled from mixed ligands of bipyridine and adipic acid through inclined polycatenatenation of three sets of 2D networks. More recently, Wang et al. reported another uranyl–organic polycatenated framework derived from 3,5-bis­(4-carboxylphenyl)­benzoic acid, an aromatic tricarboxylic acid. This unique structure exhibits high radiation and chemical stability, as well as the potential for the selective removal of cesium from aqueous solutions, which emphasizes the intriguing properties of actinide polycatenated structures. Soon afterward, Thuéry et al. prepared two 2D + 2D → 3D uranyl–organic polycatenated frameworks via dicarboxylic acids (4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylic acid or 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid) using [Ni­(bipy)3]2+ or [Ag­(bipy)2]+ counterions as the templating agent. Besides inclined polycatenatenation in the uranyl–organic coordination polymers, Thuéry et al. have recently reported an interesting case of parallel polycatenatenation, which gave a 2D + 2D → 3D framework induced by a flexible pimelate. The third type of entanglement, a Borromean-type array, has also been achieved in uranyl-based compounds by the same group utilizing long-chain aliphatic dicarboxylates.

Generally, the different types of entangled systems that have been reported can be classified as interpenetrated, polycatenated (parallel or inclined), or Borromean-linked arrays depending on the assembly patterns. Polycatenation essentially always promotes an increase in the dimensionality of the final assemblies in comparison with the dimensionality of the basic building motifs, whereas there is generally no change in the dimensionality for the interpenetration or Borromean-type assembly modes. This is also the case for uranyl-organic compounds, especially those in 2D networks, which can assemble in similar entangled patterns. For example, several uranyl-based cases, including parallel 2D + 2D → 2D interpenetration, have been reported. The first case of a polycatenatenated uranyl-organic compound, reported by Cahill in 2006, was assembled from mixed ligands of bipyridine and adipic acid through inclined polycatenatenation of three sets of 2D networks. This unique structure exhibits high radiation and chemical stability, as well as the potential for the selective removal of cesium from aqueous solutions, which emphasizes the intriguing properties of actinide polycatenated structures. Soon afterward, Thuéry et al. prepared two 2D + 2D → 3D uranyl-organic polycatenated frameworks via dicarboxylic acids (4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylic acid or 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid) using [Ni(bipy)3]2+ or [Ag(bipy)2]+ counterions as the templating agent. The third type of entanglement, a Borromean-type array, has also been achieved in uranyl-based compounds by the same group utilizing long-chain aliphatic dicarboxylates.

elements.content: Herein, we report the preparation of novel uranyl–organic polycatenated frameworks from a relatively simple organic ligand, terephthalic acid (H 2 TP). Although uranyl terephthalate (TP) compounds, or similar derivatives, have been previously reported, they include only parallel interpenetration or noninterpenetration modes, not uranyl–organic polycatenated frameworks. Previous results for uranyl–organic (inclined) polycatenated frameworks by Cahill, Wang, and Thuéry indicate that the large pore sizes (such as square or hexagonal) in the relatively rigid 2D networks are prone to promoting the inclined 2D → 3D polycatenation. A preliminary comparison between previouly reported uranyl polycatenated frameworks and uranyl terephthalate networks () reveals that the grid size of the uranyl terephthalate system (22.7 Å × 17.8 Å) is smaller than that of the uranyl/4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylic acid system (32.4 Å × 22.8 Å) but larger than that of the uranyl/3,5-bis­(4-carboxylphenyl)­benzoic acid system (17.2 Å × 11.2 Å). The modest grid size of the uranyl terephthalate system presents the possibility of assembly via an inclined polycatenated mode. Therefore, it is reasonable to speculate that, when the grid size of a 2D network is sufficiently large, polycatenated assembly of 2D networks in a pattern of inclined polycatenatenation might occur under favorable conditions. We have succeeded in the assembly of uranyl terephthalate polycatenated frameworks through a templated-synthesis method by using an organic base, 1,3-(4,4′-bispyridyl)­propane (BPP) or 4,4′-bipyridine (BPY) (), as the template agent under hydrothermal conditions. Interestingly, it has also been found that alteration of the pH or changing of the template agent can dramatically affect hydrothermal processes, resulting in a series of new uranyl terephthalate polycatenated frameworks. The structural evolution, as well as possible reaction mechanisms, is proposed, and density functional theory (DFT) calculations were conducted to explore the bonding features of the synthesized uranyl compounds.

elements.content: Caution! Because of the radioactive and chemically toxic nature of uranyl nitrate hexahydrate, UO 2 (NO 3 ) 2 ·6H 2 O, suitable precautions for safety and protection must be taken. The following reactants were used in the synthesis: uranyl nitrate hexahydrate [UO2(NO3)2·6H2O; Sinopharm Chemical Reagent, 99%], terephthalic acid (H 2 TP; Sinopharm Chemical Reagent, 99%), 1,3-(4,4′-bispyridyl)­propane (BPP; Acros, 98%), 4,4′-bipyridine (BPY; Aladdin, 98%), and ultrapure water (resistivity of 18.2 MΩ·cm–1). All commercially supplied chemical reagents were used without further purification.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

  Caution! Because of the radioactive and chemically toxic nature of uranyl nitrate hexahydrate, UO 2 (NO 3 ) 2 ⋅6H 2 O, suitable precautions for safety and protection must be taken. The following reactants were used in the synthesis: uranyl nitrate hexahydrate [UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O; Sinopharm Chemical Reagent, 99%], terephthalic acid (H  2  TP; Sinopharm Chemical Reagent, 99%), 1,3-(4,4'-bispyridyl)propane (BPP; Acros, 98%), 4,4'-bipyridine (BPY; Aladdin, 98%), and ultrapure water (resistivity of 18.2 MΩ⋅cm-1). All commercially supplied chemical reagents were used without further purification.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction measurements were made using a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) in the range 5–50° (step size: 0.02°). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a TA Q500 analyzer over the temperature range of 25–600 °C in an air atmosphere with a heating rate of 5 °C/min. The fluorescence spectra were measured on a Hitachi F-4600 fluorescence spectrophotometer equipped with a xenon lamp and solid sample holder under excitation at a wavelength of 420 nm, which is suitable for uranyl excitation. The photomultiplier tube voltage was 500 V, the excitation and emission slit widths were both 5.0 nm, and the scan speed was 60 nm/min.

elements.content:
All of the uranyl compounds in this work were hydrothermally synthesized under autogenous pressure using 15 mL Teflon-lined Parr-type autoclaves.

[UO<sub>2</sub>(<bold>TP</bold>)<sub>1.5</sub>]­(<bold>H<sub>2</sub>BPP</bold>)<sub>0.5</sub>·2H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>1</bold>)

UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (0.50 M, 0.20 mL), H2 TP (34.0 mg, 0.20 mmol), BPP (31.0 mg, 0.18 mmol), NaOH (4.0 mg, 0.10 mmol), and ultrapure water (5.0 mL) were loaded into a 15 mL autoclave. The autoclave was sealed, heated to 180 °C in an oven for 3 days, and then cooled to ambient temperature. The final pH of the aqueous solution was 4.59. Dark-yellow crystals of compound 1, accompanied by a small amount of small-size brown crystals, were produced; the yellow crystals were filtered off, rinsed with ultrapure water and ethanol, and subjected to air drying at room temperature. Yield: 3.3 mg, 5% based on uranium.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

All of the uranyl compounds in this work were hydrothermally synthesized under autogenous pressure using 15 mL Teflon-lined Parr-type autoclaves.

[UO2(TP)1.5](H2BPP)0.5⋅2H2O (1)

UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.50 M, 0.20 mL), H2  TP (34.0 mg, 0.20 mmol), BPP (31.0 mg, 0.18 mmol), NaOH (4.0 mg, 0.10 mmol), and ultrapure water (5.0 mL) were loaded into a 15 mL autoclave. The autoclave was sealed, heated to 180 °C in an oven for 3 days, and then cooled to ambient temperature. The final pH of the aqueous solution was 4.59. Dark-yellow crystals of compound 1, accompanied by a small amount of small-size brown crystals, were produced; the yellow crystals were filtered off, rinsed with ultrapure water and ethanol, and subjected to air drying at room temperature. Yield: 3.3 mg, 5% based on uranium.

elements.content: UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (0.50 M, 0.20 mL), H2TP (34.0 mg, 0.20 mmol), BPP (31.0 mg, 0.18 mmol), NaOH (10.0 mg, 0.25 mmol), and ultrapure water (5.0 mL) were loaded into a 15 mL autoclave. The autoclave was sealed, heated to 180 °C in an oven for 3 days, and then cooled to ambient temperature. The final pH of the aqueous solution was 5.71. Luminous yellow block crystals of compound 2 accompanied by a small amount of unknown brown crystals were produced; the yellow crystals were filtered off, rinsed with ultrapure water and ethanol, and subjected to air drying at room temperature. Yield: 12.4 mg, 12% based on uranium. Anal. Calcd for C58H57N4O32.5U4: C, 30.52; H, 2.52; N, 2.45. Found: C, 30.06; H, 2.56; N, 2.69.

elements.content: In order to explore the role of organic base, BPP or BPY, in the formation of uranyl terephthalate polycatenated frameworks, a set of similar hydrothermal reactions using UO2(NO3)2·6H2O and H2TP in the absence of any organic base were conducted with different amounts of NaOH solution added. This procedure yielded only transparent stick crystals of H2TP at lower pH or, at higher pH, light-yellow microcrystals that could not be characterized.
elements.clean_text:
Control Experiments without Any Organic Bases Added

In order to explore the role of organic base, BPP or BPY, in the formation of uranyl terephthalate polycatenated frameworks, a set of similar hydrothermal reactions using UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O and H2TP in the absence of any organic base were conducted with different amounts of NaOH solution added. This procedure yielded only transparent stick crystals of H2TP at lower pH or, at higher pH, light-yellow microcrystals that could not be characterized.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction data for compounds 1, 3, and 4 were all collected on a Agilent SuperNova X-ray CCD diffractometer with a Cu Kα X-ray source (λ = 1.54178 Å) at 150.01(10), 294.82(10), and 278(5) K, respectively. Standard Agilent Crysalis software was used for determination of the unit cells and data collection control. X-ray diffraction data for compound 2 were acquired using a Bruker D8 VENTURE X-ray CMOS diffractometer with a Cu Kα X-ray source (λ = 1.54178 Å) at 170(2) K. Using Olex2, all crystal structures were solved by means of direct methods (SHELXS-97 ) and refined with full-matrix least squares on SHELXL-2014. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The carbon-bound hydrogen atoms were placed at calculated positions, and all hydrogen atoms were treated as riding atoms with an isotropic displacement parameter equal to 1.2 times that of the parent atom. The structure of 2 was treated as a nonmerohedral twin, where a HKLF5 file was generated with TwinRotMat/PLATON, and the code HKLF5, in combination with BASF, was used to continue the SHELXL refinement. Refinement of the twin components in 2 converged at 0.853(3):0.147(3). Moreover, the noncentrosymmetric structure of 3 or 4 appeared to be a racemic twin, which was modeled using both the TWIN and BASF procedures. Refinement of the twin components ultimately converged at 0.432(13):0.568(13) for 3 and 0.56(2):0.44(2) for 4. The use of a DFIX (O–U, O–C) restraint was necessary to create a chemically sensible model for 4; SIMU and ISOR were used to constrain the displacement parameters of the phenyl and pyridyl groups and even out the electron density associated with disordered portions of the moieties for both 2 and 4. For all four compounds, the solvent molecules (water) as well as (part of) the organic-base cations in the structure are highly disordered and impossible to model as discrete atomic sites. To resolve this issue, the contribution of solvent–electron density was removed using the SQUEEZE/PLATON procedure, thereby producing a set of solvent-free diffraction intensities used for improving the structure refinements. Especially for the twinning cases of 2–4, the use of SQUEEZE/PLATON was based on the detwinning option in SHELXL2014, where twin.cif and twin.fcf (“LIST 8” type) from a converged SHELXL twinning refinement job (based on twin.ins including BASF/HKLF5 or BASF/TWIN records) serve as the input files. The solvent-accessible volume (SAV) and electrons found in SAV after the SQUEEZE/PLATON process are 2160.7 and 695.0 (ca. 87 electrons per cell unit) for 1, 1782.9 and 1073.8 (ca. 269 electrons per cell unit) for 2, 6824.7 and 1984.0 (ca. 248 electrons per cell unit) for 3, and 7119.2 and 2453.3 (ca. 153 electrons per cell unit) for 4, respectively. It should be mentioned that poor diffraction resulting from small dimensions, as well as the presence of twinning, leads to relatively high R 1 and wR 2 values for 2 and 4. The final formula for 2 was calculated from the crystallographic results in combination with elemental analysis and TGA. The final formula for 1 was calculated from the crystallographic results in combination with TGA as well as considering charge balance (no elemental analysis result of 1 can be referred to because of low yield), while those for compounds 3 and 4 were referenced to the crystallographic results and charge balance (no elemental analysis and TGA results of 3 and 4 can be referred to because of the lack of crystal samples in the pure phase). Considering the space and residual electronic density needed for accommodating H2 BPP or H2 BPY (H2 BPP:C13H16N2, a total of 106 electrons; H2 BPY:C10H10N2, a total of 84 electrons) and water (H2O; a total of 10 electrons), the large voids remaining in the cavities of 2D networks for all four compounds certainly contain enough room for the cations (1, 0.5 H2 BPP molecules; 2, 2 H2 BPP molecules; 3, 1 H2 BPP molecules; 1, 0.5 H2 BPP molecules) and solvent molecules (1, 2 H2O; 2, 4.5 H2O). Crystallographic data and refinement details for all four compounds are given in . Crystallographic data for all structures reported in this paper have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as supplementary publication nos. CCDC 1499906 (1), 1499907 (2), 1499908 (3), and 1499909 (4).
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Structure Determination

X-ray diffraction data for compounds 1, 3, and 4 were all collected on a Agilent SuperNova X-ray CCD diffractometer with a Cu Kα X-ray source (λ = 1.54178 Å) at 150.01(10), 294.82(10), and 278(5) K, respectively. Standard Agilent Crysalis software was used for determination of the unit cells and data collection control. X-ray diffraction data for compound 2 were acquired using a Bruker D8 VENTURE X-ray CMOS diffractometer with a Cu Kα X-ray source (λ = 1.54178 Å) at 170(2) K. Using Olex2, all crystal structures were solved by means of direct methods (SHELXS-97 ) and refined with full-matrix least squares on SHELXL-2014. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The carbon-bound hydrogen atoms were placed at calculated positions, and all hydrogen atoms were treated as riding atoms with an isotropic displacement parameter equal to 1.2 times that of the parent atom. The structure of 2 was treated as a nonmerohedral twin, where a HKLF5 file was generated with TwinRotMat/PLATON, and the code HKLF5, in combination with BASF, was used to continue the SHELXL refinement. Refinement of the twin components in 2 converged at 0.853(3):0.147(3). Moreover, the noncentrosymmetric structure of 3 or 4 appeared to be a racemic twin, which was modeled using both the TWIN and BASF procedures. Refinement of the twin components ultimately converged at 0.432(13):0.568(13) for 3 and 0.56(2):0.44(2) for 4. The use of a DFIX (O-U, O-C) restraint was necessary to create a chemically sensible model for 4; SIMU and ISOR were used to constrain the displacement parameters of the phenyl and pyridyl groups and even out the electron density associated with disordered portions of the moieties for both 2 and 4. For all four compounds, the solvent molecules (water) as well as (part of) the organic-base cations in the structure are highly disordered and impossible to model as discrete atomic sites. To resolve this issue, the contribution of solvent-electron density was removed using the SQUEEZE/PLATON procedure, thereby producing a set of solvent-free diffraction intensities used for improving the structure refinements. Especially for the twinning cases of 2-4, the use of SQUEEZE/PLATON was based on the detwinning option in SHELXL2014, where twin.cif and twin.fcf ("LIST 8" type) from a converged SHELXL twinning refinement job (based on twin.ins including BASF/HKLF5 or BASF/TWIN records) serve as the input files. The solvent-accessible volume (SAV) and electrons found in SAV after the SQUEEZE/PLATON process are 2160.7 and 695.0 (ca. 87 electrons per cell unit) for 1, 1782.9 and 1073.8 (ca. 269 electrons per cell unit) for 2, 6824.7 and 1984.0 (ca. 248 electrons per cell unit) for 3, and 7119.2 and 2453.3 (ca. 153 electrons per cell unit) for 4, respectively. It should be mentioned that poor diffraction resulting from small dimensions, as well as the presence of twinning, leads to relatively high R 1 and wR 2 values for 2 and 4. The final formula for 2 was calculated from the crystallographic results in combination with elemental analysis and TGA. The final formula for 1 was calculated from the crystallographic results in combination with TGA as well as considering charge balance (no elemental analysis result of 1 can be referred to because of low yield), while those for compounds 3 and 4 were referenced to the crystallographic results and charge balance (no elemental analysis and TGA results of 3 and 4 can be referred to because of the lack of crystal samples in the pure phase). Considering the space and residual electronic density needed for accommodating H2 BPP or H2 BPY (H2 BPP:C13H16N2, a total of 106 electrons; H2 BPY:C10H10N2, a total of 84 electrons) and water (H2O; a total of 10 electrons), the large voids remaining in the cavities of 2D networks for all four compounds certainly contain enough room for the cations (1, 0.5 H2 BPP molecules; 2, 2 H2 BPP molecules; 3, 1 H2 BPP molecules; 1, 0.5 H2 BPP molecules) and solvent molecules (1, 2 H2O; 2, 4.5 H2O). Crystallographic data and refinement details for all four compounds are given in . Crystallographic data for all structures reported in this paper have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as supplementary publication nos. CCDC 1499906 (1), 1499907 (2), 1499908 (3), and 1499909 (4).

Quantum-mechanical (QM) calculations were carried out using the Gaussian 09 program package with the B3LYP hybrid functional. For uranium, the quasi-relativistic effective core potentials (RECPs) and ECP60MWB_SEG basis sets were utilized, while the 6-31+G­(d) basis sets were used for hydrogen, carbon, and oxygen atoms. The simplified model fragments of compounds 1–4 were derived from the X-ray crystal data. Natural population analysis and molecular orbital (MO) analysis were performed at the B3LYP/RECP/6-31+G­(d) level of theory.
elements.clean_text:
Computational Methods

Quantum-mechanical (QM) calculations were carried out using the Gaussian 09 program package with the B3LYP hybrid functional. For uranium, the quasi-relativistic effective core potentials (RECPs) and ECP60MWB_SEG basis sets were utilized, while the 6-31+G(d) basis sets were used for hydrogen, carbon, and oxygen atoms. The simplified model fragments of compounds 1-4 were derived from the X-ray crystal data. Natural population analysis and molecular orbital (MO) analysis were performed at the B3LYP/RECP/6-31+G(d) level of theory.

elements.content: Compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic C2/c space group with only one 8-fold-coordinated monouranyl center in its asymmetric unit (a). The uranyl center was coordinated by three η2-carboxyls from different TP ligands, resulting in a hexagonal-bipyramidal geometry of uranyl with equatorial U–O distances from 2.436(4) to 2.481(4) Å (Table S1). Moreover, the other ends of the terephthalate ligands connect another three uranyl nodes in different directions (b) and extend to form a honeycomb-like 2D network (c) with a six-membered ring size of 22.7 Å × 17.4 Å (). It is interestingly that, unlike the bending topology of the uranyl terephthalate network reported previously, all of the atoms in the 2D network in compound 1 are nearly coplanar (d). Subsequently, on the basis of the regularity of coplanar 2D networks, no parallel interpenetration is apparent. Instead, the honeycomb-like structure of compound 1 achieves closed-packed arrangements directed by strong π–π-stacking interactions (a–c) as well as by weak hydrogen bonding (Figure S3 and Table S2) between adajcent layers with an interlayer spacing of ∼3.3 Å. Another important part in 1 is the protonated organic base molecule, H2 BPP, for charge balance, the presence of which is confirmed by the characteristic γ­(C–H) vibrations (840 cm–1) of the pyridine ring of H2 BPP found in the IR spectrum of 1 (Figure S4). Considering the close-packing structure of 1, the H2 BPP molecules might reside in the hexagonal voids of close-packing 2D layers (c).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Description

Crystal Structure of 1 

Compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic C2/c space group with only one 8-fold-coordinated monouranyl center in its asymmetric unit (a). The uranyl center was coordinated by three η2-carboxyls from different TP ligands, resulting in a hexagonal-bipyramidal geometry of uranyl with equatorial U-O distances from 2.436(4) to 2.481(4) Å (Table S1). Moreover, the other ends of the terephthalate ligands connect another three uranyl nodes in different directions (b) and extend to form a honeycomb-like 2D network (c) with a six-membered ring size of 22.7 Å × 17.4 Å (). It is interestingly that, unlike the bending topology of the uranyl terephthalate network reported previously, all of the atoms in the 2D network in compound 1 are nearly coplanar (d). Subsequently, on the basis of the regularity of coplanar 2D networks, no parallel interpenetration is apparent. Instead, the honeycomb-like structure of compound 1 achieves closed-packed arrangements directed by strong π-π-stacking interactions (a-c) as well as by weak hydrogen bonding (Figure S3 and Table S2) between adajcent layers with an interlayer spacing of ~3.3 Å. Another important part in 1 is the protonated organic base molecule, H2 BPP, for charge balance, the presence of which is confirmed by the characteristic γ(C-H) vibrations (840 cm-1) of the pyridine ring of H2 BPP found in the IR spectrum of 1 (Figure S4). Considering the close-packing structure of 1, the H2 BPP molecules might reside in the hexagonal voids of close-packing 2D layers (c).

elements.content: The structure of 2, which crystallizes in the orthorhombic Pnnm space group, contains two sets of uranyl entities as well as uncoordinated organic-base molecules (a). A detailed analysis indicates that both sets of uranyl entities, pointing in two different directions, are dimeric uranyl units (b), which give similar coordination spheres and extended structures. Besides being complexed by two bridging OH moieties, each uranyl center in the dimeric unit is also coordinated by another two TP ligands in the η2 and η1 modes, respectively, achieving a pentagonal-bipyramidal geometry of uranyl with equatorial U–O distances from 2.322(13) to 2.473(13) Å for U1 and from 2.313(9) to 2.515(12) Å for U2 (Table S1). These TP ligands further connect other uranyl nodes from different directions and finally extend to form another rhomboid-shaped 2D network (c,d). It is notable that all of the TP linkers connect two adjcent uranyl entries in an asymmetric manner: one end is in the η2 mode, and the other is in the η1 mode, which is unlike the symmetric coordination pattern of the two carboxyl groups of the TP linker in 1.

elements.content: In terms of stacking in three-dimentional space, two sets of 2D networks aligning along different directions are all polycatenated perpendicularly by each other, which affords the 2D + 2D → 3D reticular polycatenated framework of 2 (e). As mentioned above (), uranyl–organic polycatenated frameworks derived from 3,5-bis­(4-carboxylphenyl)­benzoic acid or 4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylic acid represent rare cases of previously reported actinide polycatenated frameworks. The polycatenated framework of 2 found here is another case of this type of entangled structure. Given the larger 2D network ring size (19.2 Å × 14.4 Å; see ) in 2 compared with the uranyl/3,5-bis­(4-carboxylphenyl)­benzoic acid system (17.2 Å × 11.2 Å), it is reasonable that 2 accommodates an inclined polycatenation assembly. It is notable that, unlike the monomeric uranyl node for both previous cases, this is the first uranyl polycatenated framework with oligomeric uranyl secondary building units. As shown in f, only one rod of one subset passes through each ring of the other inclined subset. All of the 2D sheets along the same orientation align in parallel with a spacing distance of 8.6 Å, which results in only one type of cavity with a size of 8.6 Å × 8.6 Å (Figure S5). Similar to the case of uranyl/4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylate, the protonated organic-base molecules, H2 BPP, are located in the voids formed in the polycatenated framework of 2 and act as the counterions forming the anionic framework (). This was confirmed by TGA of 2, which shows a distinct peak after 300 °C corresponding to the weight loss of free organic-base molecules as well as TP linkers from the uranyl–organic backbones (a total of 50.16% weight loss to the final decomposition product; Figure S7). The IR spectrum of 2 gives γ­(C–H) vibrations of the pyridine ring at 785 and 828 cm–1, which is further evidence of H2 BPP (Figure S4). Further structural analysis reveals that two types of hydrogen bonds could contribute to the stability of the polycatenated framework of 2: one type is hydrogen bonds between adjacent rods in different alignments, and the other is those related with the entrapped H2 BPP molecules (Figure S8).

This was confirmed by TGA of 2, which shows a distinct peak after 300 °C corresponding to the weight loss of free organic-base molecules as well as TP linkers from the uranyl-organic backbones (a total of 50.16% weight loss to the final decomposition product; Figure S7). The IR spectrum of 2 gives γ(C-H) vibrations of the pyridine ring at 785 and 828 cm-1, which is further evidence of H2 BPP (Figure S4). Further structural analysis reveals that two types of hydrogen bonds could contribute to the stability of the polycatenated framework of 2: one type is hydrogen bonds between adjacent rods in different alignments, and the other is those related with the entrapped H2 BPP molecules (Figure S8).

elements.content: The structure of 3, which crystallizes in the tetragonal P4̅21 c space group, consists of two different uranyl centers (U1 and U2) as well as three TP ligands in its asymmetric unit (a). Both of the uranyl centers are coordinated with three η2-carboxylate groups of TP ligands, resulting in a hexagonal-bipyramidal geometry (b). Similar to compound 1, the uranyl nodes are connected by TP ligands to achieve a honeycomb-like 2D network. However, because of the nonequivalence of U1 and U2 in 3, its coplanarity is reduced in comparison with that of 1, resulting in a bending topology when viewed from the c axis (c,d). Furthermore, in terms of crystal stacking in three-dimentional space, a 2D + 2D → 3D reticular polycatenated framework occurs again for compound 3 (e,f). A detailed analysis shows that there are two grids having two rings of one set passing through each ring from the other inclined subset. Each ring of one grid passes through two adjacent grids, which indicates a higher degree of catenation than that in 2. Interestingly, each set of two bent grids in one ring align in parallel with a spacing distance of 7.6 Å, while those adjacent bent grids in different rings align in an antiparallel mode with a maximum distance of 9.0 Å and a minimum distance of 7.9 Å (Figure S5). This distinctive assembly affords three types of irregular cavities with different sizes. Considering the different ring sizes of 2D networks in 2 and 3, the higher degree of catenation for 3 may be attributed to the larger size of the six-membered honeycomb-like ring, 23.0 Å × 17.2 Å (). Moreover, although the H2 BPP molecules are unable to be modeled in the crystallographic structures, it is believed that the large cavities in 3 can provide enough room to accommodate H2 BPP molecules as counterions. Actually, the presence of H2 BPP molecules in the crystal lattice of 3 has been proven by the IR spectrum of 3, which displays γ­(C–H)pyridine vibrations at 836 and 806 cm–1 (Figure S4). Hydrogen-bonding networks between adjacent rods in different alignments were also found, which should contribute to the cross-linking of the polycatenated framework in 3 (Figure S9 and Table S2).

elements.content: Compound 4 was synthesized by a hydrothermal reaction procedure similar to that used for compound 1, except that more rigid but smaller BPY molecules replace BPP molecules. Compound 4 crystallizes in the tetragonal I4̅2m space group. Interestingly, despite the different crystal systems and space groups for compounds 1 and 4, the asymmetric unit of 4 is identical with that of 1 (a). Accordingly, the coordination sphere of uranyl and extended honeycomb-like 2D network of 4 are also similar to those of 1 (b–d). The consistency of the basic structural unit for 1 and 4 suggests very similar crystal structures, which is consistent with the similar synthesis protocols for 1 and 4. The most striking distinction between 4 and 1 is their crystal packing structures; compound 4 achieves its lattice packing through an inclined polycatenation mode (e,f). As shown in f, two sets of grids pass perpendicularly through each ring of the other inclined subset in the polycatenated framework of 4. Similar to 3, each set of two flat layered grids in one ring align in parallel with a spacing distance of 7.9 Å, while adjacent flat layered grids in different rings align in parallel with a spacing distance of 9.1 Å (Figure S5). Hydrogen-bonding networks between adjacent rods in different alignments were also found in 4 (Figure S9 and Table S2), which should contribute to the cross-linking of the polycatenated framework. This type of assembly affords three types of regular cavities of different sizes (7.9 Å × 7.9 Å, 7.9 Å × 9.1 Å, and 9.1 Å × 9.1 Å; Figure S5). The catenation mode here can be attributed to the modest size of the six-membered ring of the 2D networks in 4 (), just as for 3 with similar honeycomb-like rings in bent 2D sheets. The γ­(C–H)pyridine vibrations at 8367 and 812 cm–1 (Figure S4) indicate the presence of H2 BPP molecules in the crystal lattice of 4, and these H2 BPP molecules should be located at the large cavities of 4.

elements.content: Compounds 1–4 were synthesized from a mixture of uranyl nitrate hexahydrate and the H2TP ligand in the presence of BPP or BPY in an aqueous medium at different pH values. The initial hydrothermal syntheses from uranyl nitrate hexahydrate, H2TP, and BPP without any NaOH added produced unkonwn light-yellow platelike microcrystal products (Figure S10a), which could not be identified by single-crystal or powder X-ray diffraction. The addition of a small amount of sodium hydroxide (NaOH/H 2 TP = 0.5–1.0) to the mixture of uranyl and H 2 TP leads to the formation of 1 with noninterpenetration of the honeycomb-like structure (Figure S10b with NaOH/H 2 TP = 0.5 at a final aqueous pH of 4.28), which is similar to the previously reported uranyl–TP systems. It is reasonable that the addition of NaOH promotes the deprotonation of H 2 TP, thus facilitating the coordination of uranyl by the terephthalate (TP) group. Increasing the amount of NaOH up to over 1 equiv (OH–/H 2 TP = 1.0–2.0), which means an elevation of the solution pH as well as more deprotonation of H 2 TP (the final pH of the aqueous solution is increased to 5.21–7.00), can promote the formation of a dimeric uranyl-mediated polycatenated framework (2; Figure S10c with NaOH/H 2 TP = 1.5 at a final aqueous pH of 6.11). As the pH of the aqueous solution under hydrothermal conditions is increased gradually, a new phase of monomeric uranyl-mediated polycatenated framework (3) begins to emerge. Detailed powder X-ray diffraction analysis () demonstrates that the crystal phase of 3 does not appear until the pH is increased to 6.61 (OH–/H 2 TP = 1.75) and becomes a significant product at a pH of 7.00 (Figure S10d with NaOH/H 2 TP = 2.0). Regarding the special role of BPP, this pH-regulated process might be related to the different behaviors of BPP at varying pH values, which exerts an indirect influence on the uranyl coordination and lattice packing. Similar regulation of supramolecular isomers has been observed in a 2,9-phenanthroline-based uranyl–organic hydrothermal system reported by our group. Interestingly, when using more rigid but small-size BPY molecules to replace BPP molecules, the polycatenated framework of compound 4 is obtained from a relatively acidic solution (NaOH/H 2 TP = 0.5, similar to that of compound 1). The remarkable structural difference between 4 and 1, which are synthesized respectively from BPY and BPP under nearly identical aqueous conditions, suggests different behaviors of BPY and BPP in mediating the assembly of uranyl terephthalate coordination systems. Overall, the preparation of compounds 1–4 displays an interesting pH-dependent evolution, which could be tuned by adjusting the acidity of aqueous solutions (). In particular, the similarity of the basic building units for 1, 3, and 4, which could be taken as different polymorphs when the counterions are neglected, suggests a crucial effect of the pH on the polymorph formation.

pH-Dependent Structural Regulation of Uranyl Terephthalate Compounds

Compounds 1-4 were synthesized from a mixture of uranyl nitrate hexahydrate and the H2TP ligand in the presence of BPP or BPY in an aqueous medium at different pH values. The initial hydrothermal syntheses from uranyl nitrate hexahydrate, H2TP, and BPP without any NaOH added produced unkonwn light-yellow platelike microcrystal products (Figure S10a), which could not be identified by single-crystal or powder X-ray diffraction. The addition of a small amount of sodium hydroxide (NaOH/H  2  TP = 0.5-1.0) to the mixture of uranyl and H  2  TP leads to the formation of 1 with noninterpenetration of the honeycomb-like structure (Figure S10b with NaOH/H  2  TP = 0.5 at a final aqueous pH of 4.28), which is similar to the previously reported uranyl-TP systems. It is reasonable that the addition of NaOH promotes the deprotonation of H  2  TP, thus facilitating the coordination of uranyl by the terephthalate (TP) group. Increasing the amount of NaOH up to over 1 equiv (OH-/H  2  TP = 1.0-2.0), which means an elevation of the solution pH as well as more deprotonation of H  2  TP (the final pH of the aqueous solution is increased to 5.21-7.00), can promote the formation of a dimeric uranyl-mediated polycatenated framework (2; Figure S10c with NaOH/H  2  TP = 1.5 at a final aqueous pH of 6.11). As the pH of the aqueous solution under hydrothermal conditions is increased gradually, a new phase of monomeric uranyl-mediated polycatenated framework (3) begins to emerge. Detailed powder X-ray diffraction analysis () demonstrates that the crystal phase of 3 does not appear until the pH is increased to 6.61 (OH-/H  2  TP = 1.75) and becomes a significant product at a pH of 7.00 (Figure S10d with NaOH/H  2  TP = 2.0). Regarding the special role of BPP, this pH-regulated process might be related to the different behaviors of BPP at varying pH values, which exerts an indirect influence on the uranyl coordination and lattice packing. Similar regulation of supramolecular isomers has been observed in a 2,9-phenanthroline-based uranyl-organic hydrothermal system reported by our group. Interestingly, when using more rigid but small-size BPY molecules to replace BPP molecules, the polycatenated framework of compound 4 is obtained from a relatively acidic solution (NaOH/H  2  TP = 0.5, similar to that of compound 1). The remarkable structural difference between 4 and 1, which are synthesized respectively from BPY and BPP under nearly identical aqueous conditions, suggests different behaviors of BPY and BPP in mediating the assembly of uranyl terephthalate coordination systems. Overall, the preparation of compounds 1-4 displays an interesting pH-dependent evolution, which could be tuned by adjusting the acidity of aqueous solutions (). In particular, the similarity of the basic building units for 1, 3, and 4, which could be taken as different polymorphs when the counterions are neglected, suggests a crucial effect of the pH on the polymorph formation.

elements.content: As a very simple aromatic acid, H 2 TP has attracted continuous research interest from inorganic chemists specialized in actinide–organic hybrid materials. Following the early work on uranyl terephthalate coordination polymers by Chen et al. and Jacobson et al., extensive exploration of new uranyl terephthalate compounds using an additional organic bases (terpyridines, 2,4,6-tris­(2-pyridyl)­striazine, 2,2′-bipyridine, or 1-[4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)-2,5-dimethylphenyl]-1H-imidazole) have been conducted. Although several noninterpenetrating or interpenetrating uranyl terephthalate networks and frameworks have been prepared (Figure S11), no uranyl terephthalate compounds with 2D → 3D polycatenated frameworks have been identified in these systems. In this work, the strategy of introducing BPP or BPY organic-base molecules into the reaction system of uranylterephthalic acid successfully promotes the formation of polycatenated frameworks under hydrothermal conditions. This inclined polycatenation assembly results in a higher degree of assembly and higher symmetry, as indicated by the crystal systems and space groups of compounds 2–4. Similar phenomena can be found for the other uranyl compounds with polycatenated frameworks, which also yield high-symmetry space groups.
elements.clean_text:
Role of BPP or BPY Organic Bases in the Formation of Uranyl Terephthalate Polycatenated Frameworks

As a very simple aromatic acid, H  2  TP has attracted continuous research interest from inorganic chemists specialized in actinide-organic hybrid materials. Following the early work on uranyl terephthalate coordination polymers by Chen et al. and Jacobson et al., extensive exploration of new uranyl terephthalate compounds using an additional organic bases (terpyridines, 2,4,6-tris(2-pyridyl)striazine, 2,2'-bipyridine, or 1-[4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)-2,5-dimethylphenyl]-1H-imidazole) have been conducted. Although several noninterpenetrating or interpenetrating uranyl terephthalate networks and frameworks have been prepared (Figure S11), no uranyl terephthalate compounds with 2D → 3D polycatenated frameworks have been identified in these systems. In this work, the strategy of introducing BPP or BPY organic-base molecules into the reaction system of uranylterephthalic acid successfully promotes the formation of polycatenated frameworks under hydrothermal conditions. This inclined polycatenation assembly results in a higher degree of assembly and higher symmetry, as indicated by the crystal systems and space groups of compounds 2-4. Similar phenomena can be found for the other uranyl compounds with polycatenated frameworks, which also yield high-symmetry space groups.

elements.content: In order to evaluate the role of BPP or BPY organic base in the formation of uranyl terephthalate polycatenated frameworks, a set of control experiments were performed under similar conditions except for the utilization of BPP or BPY (see the ). The experimental results show the formation of only transparent stick crystals of H2TP at lower pH (Figure S12a–e) or light-yellow microcrystals that could not be characterized at higher pH (Figures S12f–h and S13). The clear distinction between the reactions without BPP or BPY and those in the presence of BPP or BPY reveals the important role of the organic base for the synthesis of well-crystallized uranyl terephthalate compounds with polycatenated frameworks. We also conducted a direct comparison between the uranyl terephthalate system with BPP or BPY reported herein and previoulsy reported systems utilizing other organic bases such as 2,2′-bipyridine or 1-[4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)-2,5-dimethylphenyl]-1H-imidazole. It is interesting to find that, although there are some similarities in the molecular structures for these different organic bases, the coordination behaviors are very different. Unlike 2,2′-bipyridine or 1-[4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)-2,5-dimethylphenyl]-1H-imidazole as auxiliary ligands in the coordination sphere of the uranyl center, for BPP or BPY, this is not the case, which might be related to its mismatch in molecular size with the terephthalate ligand. This difference indicates that noncoordinated organic bases seem to be more suitable to construct polycatenated frameworks by serving as the template and cavity-filling agent, while the organic-base molecules coordinated to uranyl alter the coordination pattern of the metal center and lack cavity-filling agents. Similar templated syntheses have been observed in other previously reported uranyl–organic polycatenated frameworks based on 4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylate or 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylate ligands, where [Ni­(bipy)3]2+ or [Ag­(bipy)2]+ counterions are the templating agent for the polycatenated frameworks. It should be noted that our discussion here is specific to the uranyl terephthalate system or similar uranyl coordination polymers with a rigid aromatic carboxylate ligand system. There are exceptions for other organic ligand systems, such as a polycatenated framework found in a uranyl compound with mixed ligands of flexible adipic acid and BPY.

elements.content: Besides noncoordinated BPP or BPY organic-base molecules, other specific factors, especially reaction conditions, are also important for the construction of uranyl terephthalate polycatenated frameworks. For example, relatively acidic conditions only promote the formation of compound 1 with a 2D network structure, not a polycatenated framework, even in the presence of BPP. Similarly, a recently reported uranyl terephthalate compound with a noncoordinated 2,4,6-tris­(2-pyridyl)­striazine organic base did not form a polycatenated framework because of a lack of 2D networks as basic building blocks. Therefore, it can be concluded that the template and cavity-filling effects of organic bases (such as BPP or BPY) in combination with the specific hydrothermal conditions promote the formaion of uranyl terephthalate polycatenated frameworks.

elements.content: The fluorescence of the uranyl cation features five or six vibronic peaks in the range of 450–650 nm, which arise from electronic transitions between the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) 5f nonbonding uranyl orbitals and the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) U–O hybrid σ-bonding orbital, referred to as UO axial ligand-to-metal charge-transfer bands. Fluorescence spectra under excitation at a wavelength of 420 nm were recorded for compounds 1 and 2 (pure 3 and 4 could not be isolated in sufficient yields). As shown in , compound 1 displays quenching of uranyl luminescence, and the characteristic emission of uranyl is not observed. The geometric structure of the uranyl, as well as uranyl species, affects the fluorescence features and specific positions of the emission peaks. Unlike compound 1 in a hexagonal-bipyramidal coordination geometry, the emission spectrum of compound 2 with a pentagonal-bipyramidal geometry gives the typical vibronic progression of uranium­(VI), with the five main emission bands located at 501 (s), 521 (s), 544 (m), 569 (m), and 596 (w) nm corresponding to the S11 → S00 and S10 → S0ν (ν = 0–4) electronic transitions. These bands are red-shifted relative to those of other fluorescent uranyl–organic compounds, with similar uranyl dimer units showing pentagonal pyramids sharing a common edge [e.g., UO2(C5H6O4) and UO2(C6H8O4)]. This emission peak red shift may be attributed to the different 7-fold-coordinated environment of the uranyl center in these compounds. The most significant differences in the coordination environments are the bridging groups between the uranyl-centered polyhedra, which in compound 2 are hydroxo bridges (−OH), whereas in UO2(C5H6O4) or UO2(C6H8O4), they are μ3-oxygen atoms from ligand carboxyl groups (Figure S14). Besides the bridging groups, there are differences in the number and coordination pattern of carboxyl groups coordinated to the uranyl centers [one monodentate carboxyl and one bidentate carboxyl for compound 2; two monodentate carboxyls and half a bidentate carboxyl for UO2(C6H8O4)], as well as the types of spacers [a phenyl linker for compound 2 and a C4 linker for UO2(C6H8O4); Figure S14]. These latter structural differences likely also affect the fluorescence properties of the uranyl coordination compounds.

Besides the bridging groups, there are differences in the number and coordination pattern of carboxyl groups coordinated to the uranyl centers [one monodentate carboxyl and one bidentate carboxyl for compound 2; two monodentate carboxyls and half a bidentate carboxyl for UO2(C6H8O4)], as well as the types of spacers [a phenyl linker for compound 2 and a C4 linker for UO2(C6H8O4); Figure S14]. These latter structural differences likely also affect the fluorescence properties of the uranyl coordination compounds.

elements.content: Fluorescence spectra of compounds 1 and 2 with an excitation wavelength at 420 nm (inset: enlarged fluorescence spectrum of 1).
elements.clean_text: 10  Fluorescence spectra of compounds 1 and 2 with an excitation wavelength at 420 nm (inset: enlarged fluorescence spectrum of 1).

elements.content: As demonstrated above, the molecular structures of compounds 1–4 are all based on a uranyl terephthalate backbone but display different bonding features and topologies. In particular, compounds 1, 3, and 4, which could be taken as different polymorphs if not for the counterions, show nearly identical basic building units. To explore the nature of the metal–ligand bonding in compounds 1–4, theoretical analysis via QM calculations was conducted. To simplify this analysis, electronic structures of the model fragments of these compounds () were studied using the DFT method. For all of the model fragments, the predicted uranium atomic charges are found to be in the range of 1.38–1.54, which is much lower than that in the free UO2 2+ cation (2.81), indicating substantial charge transfer from the ligands to the uranyl centers. According to MO analysis for all of the compounds ( and S15–S17), the LUMOs are mainly concentrated on the 5f orbitals of uranium, while the HOMOs are mainly located on the ligand benzene rings. The metal–ligand σ-bonding orbitals apparent in all of these compounds mainly result from the U 5f, 6d, and 7s and O 2p orbital interactions.
elements.clean_text:
QM Calculations

As demonstrated above, the molecular structures of compounds 1-4 are all based on a uranyl terephthalate backbone but display different bonding features and topologies. In particular, compounds 1, 3, and 4, which could be taken as different polymorphs if not for the counterions, show nearly identical basic building units. To explore the nature of the metal-ligand bonding in compounds 1-4, theoretical analysis via QM calculations was conducted. To simplify this analysis, electronic structures of the model fragments of these compounds () were studied using the DFT method. For all of the model fragments, the predicted uranium atomic charges are found to be in the range of 1.38-1.54, which is much lower than that in the free UO2 2+ cation (2.81), indicating substantial charge transfer from the ligands to the uranyl centers. According to MO analysis for all of the compounds ( and S15-S17), the LUMOs are mainly concentrated on the 5f orbitals of uranium, while the HOMOs are mainly located on the ligand benzene rings. The metal-ligand σ-bonding orbitals apparent in all of these compounds mainly result from the U 5f, 6d, and 7s and O 2p orbital interactions.

elements.clean_text: 12  LUMO (a and j) and HOMO (b and k) orbitals and the main MOs (c-i and l-r) of the U-O bonding for the model fragments of compound 2.

elements.content: For compound 1 (Figure S15), the U–O σ-bonding orbital (1c orbital) contains 8% U 5f orbital character and 14% O 2p orbital character. The 1d orbital of the U–O σ bonding is composed of 12% U 7s character and 8% O 2p character. Similar to compound 1, the 4c, 4d, and 4e orbitals of compound 4 (Figure S17) correspond to the U–O σ-bonding orbitals. The former orbitals come from U 5f and O 2p orbital interactions, while the latter orbitals result from the interactions of U 5f, 6d, and 7s and O 2p orbitals. For the two model fragments of compound 2 (), similar MOs are found because of the similar structural parameters of these fragments. The 2c, 2d, 2l, 2m, and 2n orbitals correspond to the σ-bonding orbitals between the uranium and oxygen atoms of the carboxyl ligands, which show some differences in the magnitude of the orbital compositions (2c and 2d, U 5f and 6d orbitals; 2l, 2m, and 2n, U 5f or 6d orbital). Other orbitals correspond to the σ-bonding orbitals between the uranium and oxygen atoms of the bridging hydroxyl groups mainly resulting from the U 5f, 6d, and 7s and O 2p orbital interactions. For compound 3 (Figure S16), the 3c and 3d orbitals are the U–O σ-bonding orbitals originating from the interactions of U 6d and 7s orbitals and O 2p orbitals, while the 3e, 3f, 3g, and 3h orbitals represent the U–O σ-bonding orbitals resulting from U 5f and O 2p orbital interactions. In all, the DFT calculations provide insight into the uranium–ligand bonding features in compounds 1–4.

The 1d orbital of the U-O σ bonding is composed of 12% U 7s character and 8% O 2p character. Similar to compound 1, the 4c, 4d, and 4e orbitals of compound 4 (Figure S17) correspond to the U-O σ-bonding orbitals. The former orbitals come from U 5f and O 2p orbital interactions, while the latter orbitals result from the interactions of U 5f, 6d, and 7s and O 2p orbitals. For the two model fragments of compound 2 (), similar MOs are found because of the similar structural parameters of these fragments. The 2c, 2d, 2l, 2m, and 2n orbitals correspond to the σ-bonding orbitals between the uranium and oxygen atoms of the carboxyl ligands, which show some differences in the magnitude of the orbital compositions (2c and 2d, U 5f and 6d orbitals; 2l, 2m, and 2n, U 5f or 6d orbital). Other orbitals correspond to the σ-bonding orbitals between the uranium and oxygen atoms of the bridging hydroxyl groups mainly resulting from the U 5f, 6d, and 7s and O 2p orbital interactions. For compound 3 (Figure S16), the 3c and 3d orbitals are the U-O σ-bonding orbitals originating from the interactions of U 6d and 7s orbitals and O 2p orbitals, while the 3e, 3f, 3g, and 3h orbitals represent the U-O σ-bonding orbitals resulting from U 5f and O 2p orbital interactions. In all, the DFT calculations provide insight into the uranium-ligand bonding features in compounds 1-4.

elements.content: In this work, we present the assembly of uranyl–organic polycatenated frameworks from H 2 TP through a templated-synthesis method using organic bases BPP or BPY for the first time. A pH-dependent structural variation has been found that results in a series of novel uranyl terephthalate polycatenated frameworks, 2–4. DFT calculations afford detailed information on the uranium–ligand bonding features of all four compounds 1–4. A direct comparison between these polycatenated frameworks and the previously reported uranyl terephthalate compounds suggests that the template and cavity-filling effects of organic bases (such as BPP or BPY) in combination with the specific hydrothermal conditions promote the formaion of uranyl terephthalate polycatenated frameworks. The intriguing polycatenated frameworks found here enrich the family of actinide polycatenated frameworks and also provide another interesting case of pH-dependent structural regulation for uranyl compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this work, we present the assembly of uranyl-organic polycatenated frameworks from H  2  TP through a templated-synthesis method using organic bases BPP or BPY for the first time. A pH-dependent structural variation has been found that results in a series of novel uranyl terephthalate polycatenated frameworks, 2-4. DFT calculations afford detailed information on the uranium-ligand bonding features of all four compounds 1-4. A direct comparison between these polycatenated frameworks and the previously reported uranyl terephthalate compounds suggests that the template and cavity-filling effects of organic bases (such as BPP or BPY) in combination with the specific hydrothermal conditions promote the formaion of uranyl terephthalate polycatenated frameworks. The intriguing polycatenated frameworks found here enrich the family of actinide polycatenated frameworks and also provide another interesting case of pH-dependent structural regulation for uranyl compounds.

cln_elements.content:
All of the uranyl compounds in this work were hydrothermally synthesized under autogenous pressure using 15 mL Teflon-lined Parr-type autoclaves.

[UO<sub>2</sub>(<bold>TP</bold>)<sub>1.5</sub>]­(<bold>H<sub>2</sub>BPP</bold>)<sub>0.5</sub>·2H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>1</bold>)

UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (0.50 M, 0.20 mL), H2 TP (34.0 mg, 0.20 mmol), BPP (31.0 mg, 0.18 mmol), NaOH (4.0 mg, 0.10 mmol), and ultrapure water (5.0 mL) were loaded into a 15 mL autoclave. The autoclave was sealed, heated to 180 °C in an oven for 3 days, and then cooled to ambient temperature. The final pH of the aqueous solution was 4.59. Dark-yellow crystals of compound 1, accompanied by a small amount of small-size brown crystals, were produced; the yellow crystals were filtered off, rinsed with ultrapure water and ethanol, and subjected to air drying at room temperature. Yield: 3.3 mg, 5% based on uranium.

[(UO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(μ-OH)<sub>2</sub>(<bold>TP</bold>)<sub>2</sub>]<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub> <bold>BPP</bold>)<sub>2</sub>·4.5H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (0.50 M, 0.20 mL), H2TP (34.0 mg, 0.20 mmol), BPP (31.0 mg, 0.18 mmol), NaOH (10.0 mg, 0.25 mmol), and ultrapure water (5.0 mL) were loaded into a 15 mL autoclave. The autoclave was sealed, heated to 180 °C in an oven for 3 days, and then cooled to ambient temperature. The final pH of the aqueous solution was 5.71. Luminous yellow block crystals of compound 2 accompanied by a small amount of unknown brown crystals were produced; the yellow crystals were filtered off, rinsed with ultrapure water and ethanol, and subjected to air drying at room temperature. Yield: 12.4 mg, 12% based on uranium. Anal. Calcd for C58H57N4O32.5U4: C, 30.52; H, 2.52; N, 2.45. Found: C, 30.06; H, 2.56; N, 2.69.

[(UO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(<bold>TP</bold>)<sub>3</sub>]­(H<sub>2</sub> <bold>BPP</bold>) (<bold>3</bold>)

UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (0.50 M, 0.20 mL), H2TP (34.0 mg, 0.20 mmol), BPP (31.0 mg, 0.18 mmol), NaOH (16.0 mg, 0.40 mmol), and ultrapure water (5.0 mL) were loaded into a 15 mL autoclave. The autoclave was sealed, heated to 180 °C in an oven for 3 days, and then cooled to ambient temperature. The final pH of the aqueous solution was 7.00. A mixture of small yellow crystals of compound 2 and brown crystals of compound 3, accompanied by unidentified microcrystals or powder, were produced; the compounds of interest were filtered off, rinsed with ultrapure water and ethanol, and subjected to air drying at room temperature.

Synthesis

All of the uranyl compounds in this work were hydrothermally synthesized under autogenous pressure using 15 mL Teflon-lined Parr-type autoclaves.

[UO2(TP)1.5](H2BPP)0.5⋅2H2O (1)

UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.50 M, 0.20 mL), H2  TP (34.0 mg, 0.20 mmol), BPP (31.0 mg, 0.18 mmol), NaOH (4.0 mg, 0.10 mmol), and ultrapure water (5.0 mL) were loaded into a 15 mL autoclave. The autoclave was sealed, heated to 180 °C in an oven for 3 days, and then cooled to ambient temperature. The final pH of the aqueous solution was 4.59. Dark-yellow crystals of compound 1, accompanied by a small amount of small-size brown crystals, were produced; the yellow crystals were filtered off, rinsed with ultrapure water and ethanol, and subjected to air drying at room temperature. Yield: 3.3 mg, 5% based on uranium.

[(UO2)2(μ-OH)2(TP)2]2(H2 BPP)2⋅4.5H2O (2)

UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.50 M, 0.20 mL), H2TP (34.0 mg, 0.20 mmol), BPP (31.0 mg, 0.18 mmol), NaOH (10.0 mg, 0.25 mmol), and ultrapure water (5.0 mL) were loaded into a 15 mL autoclave. The autoclave was sealed, heated to 180 °C in an oven for 3 days, and then cooled to ambient temperature. The final pH of the aqueous solution was 5.71. Luminous yellow block crystals of compound 2 accompanied by a small amount of unknown brown crystals were produced; the yellow crystals were filtered off, rinsed with ultrapure water and ethanol, and subjected to air drying at room temperature. Yield: 12.4 mg, 12% based on uranium. Anal. Calcd for C58H57N4O32.5U4: C, 30.52; H, 2.52; N, 2.45. Found: C, 30.06; H, 2.56; N, 2.69.

[(UO2)2(TP)3](H2 BPP) (3)

UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.50 M, 0.20 mL), H2TP (34.0 mg, 0.20 mmol), BPP (31.0 mg, 0.18 mmol), NaOH (16.0 mg, 0.40 mmol), and ultrapure water (5.0 mL) were loaded into a 15 mL autoclave. The autoclave was sealed, heated to 180 °C in an oven for 3 days, and then cooled to ambient temperature. The final pH of the aqueous solution was 7.00. A mixture of small yellow crystals of compound 2 and brown crystals of compound 3, accompanied by unidentified microcrystals or powder, were produced; the compounds of interest were filtered off, rinsed with ultrapure water and ethanol, and subjected to air drying at room temperature.
